chunks.text: C a t w a l k A n a l y t i c s : D r e s s e s & S k i r t s S / S 2 5 Using WGSN proprietary data, we confirm the importance of day-to-night versatility, as we see shi s in lengths and silhouettes on the catwalks Lara Tutton & Madeline Chant 10.25.24 - 4 minutes F e n d i W G S N D a t a N e e d t o k n o w Opportunity Proving their importance for continued investment, dresses and skirtsʼ shares remain steady. Though the volume of dresses declined , they maintain the largest share of all catwalk apparel. Minidresses hold consistent share, while midi lengths are up (+4.3ppt). Long/maxi lengths lose share (-8.9ppt) as high-low cuts (+2.7ppt) provide a more versatile longer silhouette. Strategies Embrace bold print applications: as all- over print/pattern grows by 6.1ppt and 5.3ppt on dresses and skirts, respectively Back #MiniSkirts : which account for 30% of skirts for S/S 25. Offer variety in mini lengths using the circle silhouette (+2.1ppt) and bubble/balloon silhouettes (+1.9ppt) Invest in staple silhouettes with #Officewear and #DayToNight appeal: such as pencil/straight skirts which grew by 1.7ppt D r e s s e s a n d s k i r t s r e m a i n s t e a d y i n t h e c a t e g o r y m i x W o m e n ’ s c a t w a l k a p p a r e l % m i x W G S N C a t w a l k s . S / S 2 5 a n d S / S 2 4 3 . 4 p p t 1 . 0 p p t 0 . 3 p p t C o n t r a s t d e t a i l s ( 1 4 % ) T i e r s ( 8 % ) T w o - i n - o n e ( 3 % ) P l e a t s / p l e a t e d ( 1 3 % ) P e p l u m ( 1 % ) R u c h i n g / s h i r r i n g ( 4 % ) 0 W G S N . c o m K n e e l e n g t h s i n c r e a s e f o r S / S 2 5 , w h i l e m i n i / s h o r t s t y l e s r e t a i n t h e i r s h a r e L e n g t h % m i x o f c a t e g o r y & Y o Y p p t c h a n g e W G S N C a t w a l k s . S / S 2 5 a n d S / S 2 4 1 1 . 1 p p t 0 - 3 . 8 p p t - 4 . 7 p p t K n e e l e n g t h ( 2 6 % ) M i n i / s h o r t ( 3 0 % ) M i d i / m i d - c a l f ( 2 1 % ) L o n g / m a x i ( 2 0 % ) 0 W G S N . c o m 3 K e y t r e n d s A er seasons of limited representation, print makes a strong return to the S/S 25 catwalks. Invest in bold applications of all-over print, up 6.1ppt and 5.3ppt on dresses and skirts respectively. Capitalise on familiar classics to appease print-cautious consumers and focus on florals, which increase by 6.2ppt on dresses and 2.2ppt on skirts.

Invest in bold applications of all-over print, up 6.1ppt and 5.3ppt on dresses and skirts respectively. Capitalise on familiar classics to appease print-cautious consumers and focus on florals, which increase by 6.2ppt on dresses and 2.2ppt on skirts. Maxi lengths remain the most popular dress lengths, accounting for 33% of styles. However, on the S/S 25 catwalks, they lost share (-8.9ppt) while also declining in skirts (-4.7ppt). Balance your assortments by testing knee-length styles, which are surging in popularity at +5.2ppt for dresses and +11.1ppt for skirts. Though dipping by 0.5ppt in skirts, bubble/balloon silhouettes increase by 1.9ppt in dress categories. Invigorate popular mini lengths by applying #BubbleHems . Extend this fresh focus on #So Volume into sleeves too, as #PuffSleeves remain reliably popular, increasing by 0.4ppt. Reflecting S/S 25ʼs focus on romantically feminine aesthetics, knit/jersey fabrics lose share to #Sheers and #Lace . Sheers increased by 0.5ppt in skirts and 1.5ppt in dresses, where they now account for 20% of the mix. #UnderwearOuterwear trends are key for both dresses and skirts, while #LayeredSheers provide a commercial entry point in conservative markets. Decreasing by 4.9ppt, evening/special occasion silhouettes show the largest decline in skirts. This shi away from formal dress codes is reflected in dress categories too, as evening gowns decline by 10.1ppt.

Decreasing by 4.9ppt, evening/special occasion silhouettes show the largest decline in skirts. This shi away from formal dress codes is reflected in dress categories too, as evening gowns decline by 10.1ppt. Prioritise #DayToNight styling on skirts by applying versatile two-in-one details (+1ppt) and #Fringing embellishments (+4.1ppt). Versace Zimmermann Ulla Johnson Atlein Emporio Armani 4 ▲ + 6 . 1 p p t All-over print/pattern ▼ - 8 . 9 p p t Long/maxi ▲ + 1 . 9 p p t Bubble/balloon ▲ + 1 . 9 p p t Sheers ▼ - 4 . 9 p p t Evening/special occasion F u r t h e r r e s e a r c h C a t w a l k s : W o m e n ’ s K e y I t e m s - D r e s s e s S / S 2 5 C a t w a l k s : W o m e n ’ s K e y I t e m s - S k i r t s S / S 2 5 C a t w a l k s : W o m e n ‘ s K e y I t e m s – E v e n i n g & S p e c i a l O c c a s i o n S / S 2 5 C a t w a l k A n a l y t i c s : P r i n t s S / S 2 5 K e y I t e m s F a s h i o n : W o m e n ’ s D r e s s e s S / S 2 5 5 M e t h o d o l o g y W G S N C a t w a l k A n a l y t i c s WGSN is supplied with images covering all the major catwalk shows and pre-season collections. Each look is classified into its individual garments by WGSN Fashion Vision, our AI image recognition tool. This ensures the tags apply at a garment level, not just to the whole look, and enables us to get accurate counts for each product classification The garments are then given further keywords for style, silhouette, neckline, length, print and pattern, detail, embellishment and fabric.

Each look is classified into its individual garments by WGSN Fashion Vision, our AI image recognition tool. This ensures the tags apply at a garment level, not just to the whole look, and enables us to get accurate counts for each product classification The garments are then given further keywords for style, silhouette, neckline, length, print and pattern, detail, embellishment and fabric. This process is completed by our panel of fashion-trained image taggers. Each image is quality- checked for accuracy by this in-house team This report uses data based on the S/S 25 shows across New York, London, Milan and Paris tagged as of October 9 and compares it with tagged data from the S/S 24 shows Future reportsʼ numbers may fluctuate as we continue to tag and classify images D e n i t i o n s Product, assortment or category mix (% mix): proportion of a set of products over a larger set. An example is the volume of dresses over the whole volume of apparel Percentage point (ppt): a percentage is the proportion of a set of products over a larger set. An example is new-in trousers over new-in apparel mix. A percentage point computes the arithmetical difference between percentages. Going from 40% to 44% is a 4ppt increase Prior seasonsʼ Catwalk Analytics reports included YoY % change. However, WGSN has transitioned to using YoY ppt Change to showcase year-on-year shi s in % mix 6
